content.description: Starts slightly overhung with both hands matched on a good ledge and with feet out to the left, then a right hand move to a great crimped, then heel hook the start hold with the left foot and move your left hand to a decent sloper above the right hand crimp. From here, there's a dynamic move to a great right hand pinch where you lose your feet and try not to lose your left hand, then you can follow an easy line of crimps to a top out.
content.protection: There are lots of large rocks on the ground that could be very dangerous to fall on, but it's not very long so you can get away with 1-2 decently sized pads and a spotter, just make sure they cover the ground rocks.
content.location: After coming down the trail to the bank of the reservoir from Roadside Rock, turn right. Keep walking until you reach a large, free standing boulder that looks like a nugget. If you turn the corner or reach water, you've gone too far.

content.description:
Both hands start on a sloppy crimp , then it's a a fairly dynamic move to good sloper with the right hand, and finally a dyno to catch a good left hand crimp at the top and a top out.

Ideal climber height for this is ~5'7". Tall enough to reach the sloper, but still has to jump for the top crimp.

Many variants of this climb can be done to make it easier, but be careful of rocks breaking off the top and if you use any holds not described.
content.protection: Can be done safely with 0-1 pads with a spotter. It's pretty much straight up and not too high so you can land on your feet in most cases. Be careful of breaking holds though, the rock is a little chossy.
content.location: After going down the trail from Roadside Rock to get to the bank of the reservoir, turn left. Walk until the banks curve inwards a little bit and where there's a small chasm you have to cross, then look up at the tree line. You will see a large, dark rock towards the top. The climb is on the most vertical part of the rock, facing the water.
